qas.question: What finance act affected the 2004 election?

answers.text: the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002

qas.question: Where did the moniker McCain-Feingold Bill come from?

answers.text: its sponsors in the United States Senate

qas.question: How did the 527 groups come up with their title?

answers.text: Named for a section of the Internal Revenue Code

qas.question: What stipulation enabled the 527 groups to campaign for funds?

answers.text: as long as they do not coordinate their activities with political campaigns

qas.question: What is one of the named 527 groups from the 2004 election?
What act was passed during the 2000 campaign?
What reforms took place during the 2000 campaign?
How many campaign finance groups were there in 2000?
In what year did McCain run for President of the US?
What group supported McCain in the 2000 election?

context: The 2004 election was the first to be affected by the <b6_0>campaign finance reforms<b6_0/> mandated by <a0_0><b5_0>the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act<b5_0/> of 2002<a0_0/> (also known as the McCain–Feingold Bill for <a1_0>its sponsors in the United States Senate<a1_0/>). Because of the Act's restrictions on candidates' and parties' fundraising, a large number of so-called <b7_0>527<b7_0/> groups emerged. <a2_0>Named for a section of the Internal Revenue Code<a2_0/>, these groups were able to raise large amounts of money for various political causes <a3_0>as long as they do not coordinate their activities with political campaigns<a3_0/>. Examples of 527s include Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, <a4_0>MoveOn.org<a4_0/>, the Media Fund, and <b9_0>America Coming Together<b9_0/>. Many such groups were active throughout the campaign season. (There was some similar activity, although on a much lesser scale, during the <b8_0>2000<b8_0/> campaign.)
